title: 105_s638
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument Completion Act". Congress finds that the Act required the acquisition of all land in the Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument, with separate exchanges for surface and mineral/geothermal interests. While the surface interests exchange was completed on time, the mineral and geothermal interests exchange remains unfinished over a decade later. The Act mandated the acquisition of private mineral and geothermal interests within the Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument, which remains incomplete over a decade later. The purpose of the Act is to expedite the completion of this acquisition. The Act mandates the acquisition of mineral rights within the National Volcanic Monument to expedite completion. Section 3 of the Act designating the Mount St. Helens National Volcanic Monument is amended to expedite the completion of mineral and geothermal interests acquisitions. The term 'holder' is defined as a company or its successor. The Secretary of the Interior is required to acquire mineral and geothermal interests in the Monument from holders within a specified period. In exchange, monetary credits will be issued to the holders for payment of a portion of the bonus or other payments from mineral leases under the Mineral Leasing Act. The Secretary of the Interior is required to acquire mineral and geothermal interests in the Monument from holders within a specified period. In exchange, monetary credits will be issued to the holders for payment of a portion of the bonus or other payments from mineral leases under the Mineral Leasing Act, Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, or Geothermal Steam Act of 1970. The credits issued shall equal the fair market value of all mineral and geothermal interests conveyed in the exchange as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary of the Interior will accept credits issued for payments in the same manner as cash. The use of credits must comply with relevant laws. Credits accepted by the Secretary will be considered as money received for specific purposes under relevant acts. The mineral and geothermal interests to be conveyed in exchanges must be valued within 120 days using specified methods, including adjusting values based on the consumer price index. The Department of Labor published consumer values for exchange, to be agreed upon within 30 days of enactment. Qualified appraiser selection required within the same timeframe. The Department of Labor published consumer values for exchange, to be agreed upon within 30 days of enactment. Qualified appraiser selection required within the same timeframe, with a process outlined if no agreement is reached. The appraisers must choose a third qualified appraiser to conduct the appraisal with guidance from designated appraisers. The valuation date for mineral and geothermal interests is set as August 26, 1982, adjusted for changes. The Secretary of the Interior will bear the costs of the appraisal process for mineral and geothermal interests. The appraisal report must be timely presented to determine the value of the interests. The Secretary of the Interior will notify holders of the value of mineral and geothermal interests within 180 days. If a determination is not made or holders disagree, they can petition the United States Court of Federal Claims for a value determination. The Secretary of the Interior will establish an exchange account for holders within 30 days after each exchange, containing monetary credits from the mineral and geothermal interests conveyed. The Court's determination on value is binding for all parties involved. The exchange account holds credits based on the value of mineral and geothermal interests conveyed. Credits can be used for specified purposes and transferred or sold to others. The Secretary of the Interior adjusts credit balances to reflect payments made. The exchange account holds credits that can be transferred or sold to qualified individuals holding mineral, oil, or gas leases. The holder must notify the Secretary of the Interior of any transfers promptly. There is a time limit on the use of credits. On the date that is 5 years after an account is created, the Secretary of the Interior will terminate the account and any remaining credits will become unusable. Title to mineral and geothermal interests held by the account holder will transfer to the United States upon establishment of an exchange account. The exchanges under paragraph (2) must be completed within 180 days of enactment or as soon as practicable. Upon completion of the exchange process, the account will be terminated within 5 years, and any remaining credits will become unusable. The bill was passed by the Senate on July 17, 1998, as confirmed by Secretary Gary Sisco.
